caseTitle: WELFORD QUARCOO VRS THE ATTORNEY-GENERAL, THE ELECTORAL COMMISSION
summary: In Welford Quarcoo v. The Attorney-General & The Electoral Commission (2012), the plaintiff challenged the constitutionality of several provisions of the Local Government Act, 1993 (Act 462), particularly those empowering the President to create districts and municipalities by executive instrument and to direct the Electoral Commission. The plaintiff argued that such powers violated Articles 241(2), 106(1), and 45 of the 1992 Constitution by undermining parliamentary sovereignty and public participation. The Supreme Court dismissed the suit, relying on its contemporaneous decision in Naakarley Amegatcher v. Attorney-General, which upheld the constitutionality of the same provisions, affirming that legislative delegation to the executive in this context was lawful.
citations: Naakarley Amegatcher v. Attorney-General and Electoral Commission (Suit No. J1/8/2012)
Okane & Ors v. Electoral Commission and the Attorney-General
Nii Tetteh Opremreh v. The Electoral Commission and the Attorney-General
rationaleHighlights: The Court relied on its contemporaneous decision in Naakarley Amegatcher, which upheld the constitutionality of the challenged provisions.
Delegation of district creation power to the President under Act 462 was deemed lawful and consistent with the Constitution.
The Court rejected the argument that such delegation undermines parliamentary sovereignty and public participation.
Executive instruments (E.I. 80, 81, 82) for creating districts and municipalities were upheld as valid.
The plaintiff's purposive interpretation favoring enhanced public participation was not accepted.
The judgment emphasized that the President's role in introducing financial bills and assenting to legislation provides sufficient executive-legislative balance.
The Court found no violation of Articles 241(2), 106(1), or 45 of the 1992 Constitution.
The dismissal was based on binding precedent, leaving no discretion for a different outcome.
